context: So how do Christians who believe in ‚Äúcreation theory‚Äù deal with the fact that dinosaurs existed long before the earth was ‚Äúcreated‚Äù?

replies.context:
They didn't. The "millions of years" you hear about is the fiction. The isotopic dating techniques used to date the earth and its rocks are so full of tenuous assumptions as to be meaningless, unless you are bent on "proving" Darwinian macroevolution. Some of these assumptions are:
The proportion of "parent" and "daughter" isotopes were known when the rock was formed.
None of the "parent" or "daughter" materials entered or escaped the rock in question during the "millions of years" it existed.
The rate of radioactive decay remained constant throughout the specimen's life.
There are other assumptions involved as well. The bottom line: when volcanically formed rocks known to be only 2 - 20 years old are tested by the dating labs, the results routinely "show" them to be hundreds of thousands of years old. This has been documented scores of times.

Fossils are found in sedimentary rock - they were buried with dirt and rocks washed over the animal bodies during a violent flood. It is impossible to know the age of the fossils themselves from the surrounding rocks.

The Bible doesn't use the word, "dinosaur", because it wasn't coined yet. Look at the verses on the behemoth and it is a good description of a sauropod. The description of the leviathon could be about mosasaurs or other extinct aquatic reptiles. Similarly, dragons may refer to extinct flying reptiles such as pterodactyls.
Everything you just said is wrong. Now go back to the fiction section.
Where do you get such unscientific garbage from?  Your argument is ridiculously illogical

Well first of all if the decay rate of isotopes is not constant, then the Heisenburg Uncertainty Principle is completely wrong, and if it's wrong, then the periodic table is an unexplained mystery, and if that's true, then basically everything we know about chemistry must be wrong, and if that's the case, biology itself must be wrong, and if that's true, modern medicine cannot possibly work. 

I wonder if the above is all true or if creationists are a bunch of lying fools.

Yeah that's always such a cute argument from non-scientists who don't understand how the process works. They are not 'guessing' at anything. Bones have more than just names and most of the major bones have names for every bump, ridge, dip, hole and process. 

They're not "guessing", they're looking at remains and making very educated assertions based on a vast wealth of knowledge.

As an assertion is a statement that one strongly believes is true it is not a fact. Paleontologists deal with assumptions and beliefs about the very, very small amount of actual fact that they have to work with... Unless they build a time machine or reproduce a triceratops from ancient DNA they will never be 100% certain whether or not they are correct.

And DNA wouldn't give them a 100% certain answer either because DNA isn't like that for things like this :D

There are few "absolute" certainties in science, just mountains and mountains of evidence that make something incredibly likely to be true based on the evidence.

But that's still not "guessing".

It may be a sign of my age but I dislike "theories" touted as fact. That's probably more the result of media reporting on science than a true scientist's claims. Most people today take what they read on the Internet as gospel, they don't understand the "educated guesswork" that is the basis of the scientific method.

I live Down Under and have followed this story for years. The dinosaur skeleton was found about 2 hours west of Eromanga in Queensland, and has done wonderful things for this little but wonderful small town. I live on a little island off the coast of South Queensland and look forward to visiting the site of our wonderful dinosaur. Once the Covid  thing has passed all you USA people must visit up here, it's a great place.Best wishes to all.

replies.context: there are many dino discoveries waiting to happen in Oz - but how long it will take to play out is anyone's guess; however, the vast number of placental mammal fossils from the Cenozoic of 20,000 years ago and more are also incredibly interesting - Australia was more rainy and bursting with wildlife then
